channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: El Salvador Advises Against Pregnancy Until 2018 in Answer to Zika Fears
item.description: The rapid spread of the mosquito-borne virus, which has been linked to a surge in malformed infants, has forced Latin America to take extreme health measures.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: La Loche, the Canadian Town Where 4 Were Killed, Has a Bleak History
item.description: The community has high levels of unemployment and addiction to drugs and alcohol, and there have been waves of suicides, mostly among young residents.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: A man holding a rosary on Saturday outside the school in La Loche, Saskatchewan, where two of the victims were fatally shot.

item.title: Iraqi Leader Asks U.S. for Help to Train Police Forces, Officials Say
item.description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said that even minimal training significantly enhanced their ability to maintain control of Ramadi.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Afghan Officials, Voicing Security Fears on Facebook, Are Fired for Their Trouble
item.description: Complaints on social media by two deputy governors besieged by Taliban, Qaeda and Islamic State fighters were not viewed kindly by the government of President Ashraf Ghani.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Afghan tribesmen taking the coffins of seven relatives killed by militants to Kabul in a high-profile protest march in November.

item.title: Crackdown by Egypt Draws Attention to an Anniversary It Aimed to Avoid
item.description: Many in Egypt are baffled by the scale of a clampdown aimed at preventing any protest commemorating the Jan. 25, 2011, uprising that toppled former President Hosni Mubarak.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the ouster of Hosni Mubarak filled Tahrir Square in Cairo on Feb. 1, 2011.

item.title: A Lake in Bolivia Evaporates, and With It a Way of Life
item.description: Lake Poopó was officially declared evaporated in December, forcing many people to leave the area.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: NASA images show Lake Poopó in Untavi with water in 2013, left, and almost dry by January 2016.

item.title: U.S. Prisoner Who Stayed in Iran Was F.B.I. Consultant, Expatriate News Service Says
item.description: The prisoner, Nosratollah Khosravi, was the only American prisoner who did not depart Iran after a deal to swap prisoners was announced a week ago.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: David Stoliar, Survivor of World War II Disaster, Dies at 91
item.description: Mr. Stoliar was the only survivor among nearly 800 Jews fleeing Romania’s Holocaust aboard a ship that was barred from Palestine, interned by Turkey, set adrift and torpedoed by a Soviet submarine.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN
item.media:description: The refugee ship Struma in the Istanbul harbor in February 1942. Turkey held the ship for 71 days before towing it out to sea.

item.title: U.S. Relies Heavily on Saudi Money to Support Syrian Rebels
item.description: A joint arming and training program between the C.I.A. and Saudi Arabia reflects the enduring alliance between the nations even as their relationship and the kingdom’s place in the region are in flux.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Shiite Muslims in Karachi, Pakistan, protested the Saudis’ beheading of a dissident cleric this month. The Obama administration did not publicly condemn it.

item.title: U.S. Student’s Detention by North Korea Was a Surprise, Tour Group Says
item.description: There were no signs that an American student, Otto F. Warmbier, who is being held in North Korea, had not engaged in “anti-state” behavior, a tour group member said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Terrorism Charges in Bangladesh for 14 Men Deported From Singapore
item.description: A group of men deported on suspicion of involvement with militant networks were charged, though Bangladesh said there was no evidence that they were planning an attack.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: As Frustrations With Mexico’s Government Rise, So Do Lynchings
item.description: The actions are born of a sense of hopelessness and impotence in the country, where 98 percent of murders go unsolved and many crimes are not even reported.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: A truck on fire near the place where two men were lynched and burned to death by an angry crowd in the main square of Ajalpan in October.

item.title: Palestinian Girl With Knife Killed by Israeli Guard, Police Say
item.description: The police in Israel said the 13-year-old girl was shot by a civilian guard outside a West Bank settlement after running at him with a knife.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Four Killed in Saskatchewan School Shooting
item.description: Others were wounded in the shooting in the northern Saskatchewan town of La Loche, but the police offered few details.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: North Korea Says It’s Holding U.S. Student for ‘Hostile Act’
item.description: The University of Virginia student has been accused of entering the North to bring “down the foundation of its single-minded unity.”
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A North Korean soldier in Pyongyang in October. An American student, Otto Frederick Warmbier, was accused of entering the North with the intent of “bringing down the foundation of its single-minded unity.”

item.title: Spain’s Acting Prime Minister Declines Invitation to Form Government
item.description: Mariano Rajoy’s decision, after an week of talks between King Felipe VI and the leaders of Spain’s main parties, prolongs the country’s political deadlock.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Clues Emerge on Robert Levinson, C.I.A. Consultant Who Vanished in Iran
item.description: Newly disclosed documents conflict with Iran’s claim it knew nothing about the consultant Mr. Levinson who disappeared in Iran in 2007.
item.dc:creator: BARRY MEIER
item.media:description: Robert Levinson, who disappeared in Iran in 2007.

item.title: France Plans a New Keyboard to Shift Control to Typists
item.description: The AZERTY keyboard, whose shortcomings make it hard to type common characters, has never been standardized, and the Culture Ministry has asked for changes.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Haiti Postpones Presidential Runoff as Violence Rises
item.description: The decision to delay the second round of voting came less than 48 hours before polling stations were to open.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Protesters on Friday in the Pétionville area of Port-au-Prince. Electoral officials did not announce a new date for the vote or explain what happens after the current president’s term ends on Feb. 7.

item.title: Fears About China’s Economy Fester at Davos
item.description: As fingers point to China as a source of economic concern, its supporters note its potential for growth.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:description: From left, Jiang Jianqing, Christine Lagarde, Fang Xinghai and Gary Cohn at a Davos session.
